title: SB 1.18.27-28 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 17-04-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: Om Agyanati Mirandhsya Gyananjanishalakaya Chaksharunmeenitam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
Namah Om Vishnupadaya Krishna Preshtaya Bhutale Shri Mate Bhaktivedanta Swamin Nithinamine
Namaste Saraswate Deve Gauravani Pracharine Nirvishesha Shunyavadi Paschatya Deshatarine
Jaya Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda Shri Advaita Gadadhara Shiva Sadhigaura Bhakta Vrinda
Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Chai Vanarottamam
Deveem Saraswateem Vyasam Tato Jayam Udi Rayet
In this session we will be discussing from two words.
The 27th and the 28th verses of the 18th chapter of the first canto.
So the 27th verse to begin this session.
Vipra Kirna Jatachannam Rauravena Jinenacha Vishushyat Talur Udakam Tathabhutam Ayachata
The meaning of this verse is
The sage in meditation was covered by the skin of a stanchion
And long compressed hair was scattered all over him
The king whose palate was dry from thirst asked him for water
So you just try to picturize what's happening
Pariksit Maharaj has gone hunting
And he became very tired, thirsty and hungry
And he started searching for water
And he came across this muni's ashram
Shastra of the sage in meditation
Shamika Rishi's ashram
He entered inside and saw the sage is sitting in meditation
And the way king Pariksit saw the muni is being described here further
That the sage that is Shamika Rishi
Who was sitting in meditation was covered by skin of a stanchion
These rishis they don't wear regular clothes
Because they are in the forest
So the sage was sitting in meditation
So they cover themselves with some skin of an animal
Or a bark of a tree
Something easily available
And that need not be changed
That need not be washed
Just because they sit for meditation for very long time
So they have no time to maintain all those things
And long compressed hair was scattered all over him
There's no time to do that
trim the hair or shave etc so the compressed hair is everywhere over his
body and this king Parikshit he was very very thirsty so thirsty that his palate
or his tongue was completely dry and he entered and he asked for water because
he was very very thirsty so Srila Prabhupada says in the purport the king
being thirsty asked the sage for water something very natural and very simple
that such a great devotee and King asked for water from a sage absorbed in trance
was certainly providential something unexpected something not expected from a
devotee
Parikshit is a devotee and he is aware that he is entering the ashram of a
Rishi and the Rishi is sitting in meditation obviously you don't expect the
Rishi will be when he's sitting in meditation and deeply absorbed in
meditation you don't expect him to be conscious
that some guest has come or somebody has come asking for water you wouldn't
expect that so and in spite of that because the king was very very very
thirsty he's desperately looking for water so he just asked just asked so it
is something which is extraordinary because Prabhupada says here otherwise
there was no chance of such a unique happening it is very very unique this is
an incident arranged by the Supreme Lord for Bhagavatam to be spoken by Shukadev Goswami
on enquiry of Parikshit Maharaj. All these descriptions are events leading to that extraordinary
meeting of Parikshit and Shukadev Goswami leading to the Srimad Bhagavatam being spoken.
So Maharaj Parikshit just placed an awkward position so that gradually Srimad Bhagavatam
could be revealed. This is what Prabhupada says. 28th verse further description, Alabdha
Trna Bhumi Adihi, Asam Prapt Argya Soondrata, Avagyatam Ivaatmanam Manya Manas Chukopah,
the meaning of this 28th verse. The king not received by any formal welcome by means of
being offered a seat, a place, water and sweet addresses, considered himself neglected and
so thinking he became angry. This is describing King Parikshit. What was his reaction? He
thought I have come to his Muni's ashram. And the Muni is not angry. He is not angry.
He is responding. He is indifferent to my having come here. He is not offering a seat
or place to sit down. No welcome and no water and no sweet talk. So he considered that I
have been neglected. Very basic etiquette is not being followed. I have been neglected
and he became angry. So Prabhupada explains in the purport.
So the background for this verse being this this description by Suta Goswami. The law of
reception in the courts of the Vedic principles state that even if an enemy is received at
home he must be received with all respects. This is the Vedic culture. Whoever it is,
when they come to your house, enemy or friend, a stranger or a known person, you have to
receive that person with all respect. This is very important. After you get to the be
all respects the visitor should not be given a chance to understand that he has
come into the house of an enemy if he happens to be an enemy and proper gives
an example here when Lord Krishna accompanied by Arjuna and Bhima
approached Jarasandha in Magadha the respectable enemies were given a royal
reception by King Jarasandha enemy means enemy camp Jarasandha belongs to
the camp of the Asuras headed by Kamsa and Krishna Arjuna Bhima the Pandavas
they belong to the camp of devotees and Supreme Lord
obviously
so when Krishna Arjuna and Bhima approached Jarasandha they were in disguise so even
though they were in disguise when Jarasandha tried to inquire who are you because he could
not recognize their external features they disguised themselves so then when they reveal
their identity still Jarasandha understood these are my enemies but still he received them with a
royal reception this is very cultural and it is also told in the Mahabharata the guest enemy
namely Bhima was to fight with Jarasandha
that the purpose for which Krishna Bhima and Arjuna had gone and yet they were given a grand
reception so at night they used to sit down together as friends and guests and in the
daytime they used to fight risking life and death that was a law of reception in their fighting and
one of them will be defeated and killed still
that is only due to the daytime the fight is going on Bhima versus Jarasandha at night the
fight is not concluded at the end of day one day two day three four for so many days so when the
fight has not been decided they at the night they will be like Bhima Arjuna and Krishna are guests
of Jarasandha so they'll be nicely given a place to stay they'll be given a nice food nice talk
everything very nice now further Prabhupada says the Vedic etiquette the reception law enjoins that a
poor man was nothing to offer his guest very poor should be good enough to offer a straw mat for
sitting a glass of water for drinking and some sweet words so Prabhupada says therefore to receive
a guest either a friend or foe somebody is an enemy
not an enemy is a friendly person there is no expense it is only a question of good manners
very culture is the poorest of poor man when he receives somebody at home he still offers a good
reception simply by offering a straw mat straw mat means some straws which are available anywhere
they just woven together and made into a sitting mat
so straw mat some water to drink water is available everywhere you know poor man is plenty
of water earlier there is to live always by a water source either a river or a nice pond or
lake or a nice well and plenty of water always there is water so water even a poorest of poor
man can offer a straw mat he can offer to the guest
he can offer sweet words welcome to my humble abode please come sit down accept some water
what can I do for you so sweet words can be offered without any expense so it is question
of good manners now Prabhupada explains when Maharaj Pariksit entered the door of Shamika
Rishi he did not expect a royal reception by the Rishi because he knew that saints and Rishis are
not material rich persons they are living in an ashram they are not material rich persons they are living in an ashram
they are living in an ashram they are not material rich persons they are living in an ashram
some hut and where can they offer royal reception even the king because King
deserves a royal reception but how can they offer a royal reception so Pariksit
did not expect a royal reception but he never expected that a seed of straw a
glass of water and some sweet words would be denied to him he was not an
ordinary guest nor was he an enemy of the Rishi and therefore the cold
reception with the Rishi was not an ordinary guest nor was he an enemy of the Rishi and
therefore the cold reception with the Rishi was not an ordinary guest nor was he an enemy of the Rishi and astonished the King greatly why am I
astonished the King greatly why am I being denied even some basic reception I
being denied even some basic reception I just want some water that's all and even
just want some water that's all and even that water is being denied by this Rishi
that's what thinking of Pariksit Maharaj is so going by the etiquette that is
expected the king was right to get angry with the Rishi when he needed a glass of
water very badly so Papa says in the elecmosis to become angry in such a
grave situation was not unnatural for the king but this special circumstance
here what is that because the King himself was not less than a great saint
he was saintly king rajarshi Pariksit was not ordinary king his
becoming angry and taking action were astonishing very the muni is sitting in
trance he is engaged in spiritual activities he is cut off from external
sense perception he is absorbed within completely and you expect that such a meditating sage he's
going to offer you some reception he's going to give some water he's conscious that you have
come to his ashram no so why is King Pariksit becoming angry that is a question that should
be raised so proper says it must be accepted that this situation was ordained by the supreme will
of Lord Krishna the king was a great devotee of the Lord and the saint that is Samika Rishi was
also as good as the king in saintly conduct but by the will of the Lord the circumstances
are so created that they became ways to
the kings becoming unattached to family connection and governmental activities and thus becoming
a surrendered soul unto the lotus feet of Lord Krishna the events led to that and that
we described in the next few verses the merciful Lord sometimes creates such awkward position
for his pure devotees in order to drag the pure devotee towards himself
from the mire of material existence mire means that entangling situations in this material world
the Lord wants to pull out every one of us but the pure devotees is particularly conscious come
out quickly out of this material existence and come back to me outwardly the situations appear
to be frustrating to the devotees but the devotees of the Lord are always under the
protection of the Lord and in any condition frustration of success
the Lord is a supreme guide for the devotees devotees understand if there is some frustrating
situation they know it is the arrangement of the Lord Lord has got a higher plan otherwise the
devotees are never put in frustrating situation in inconvenience they execute the devotional service
peacefully but sometimes in spite of their endeavor to execute devotional service they put in a
situation where is difficulty even for doing devotional service and that is the Lord has
got a higher plan
devotees therefore accept all conditions of frustration as blessings from the
Lord and that's what happened in the case of Parikshit Maharaj I'll stop here
thank you very much Hare Krishna. He has got a higher plan. The pure devotees therefore
accept all conditions of frustration as blessings from the Lord and that's what
happened in the case of Parikshit Maharaj. I'll stop here thank you very much Hare Krishna.
